intro: Ammannia parvula, commonly known as the smallflower ammannia, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the family Lythraceae, which includes plants such as poinsettias and water willows. The plant typically grows in wetland habitats, including marshes and along the edges of ponds. It produces small, pinkish-white flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are simple, opposite, and often covered in fine hairs, contributing to its distinctive botanical appearance.
